Implement dynamic worker scaling based on task availability
description:
Dynamically scale worker count based on available work:

Current: Fixed worker count regardless of available tasks
Problem: Idle workers when no tasks, wasted resources

Goals:
- Scale down workers when no tasks available
- Scale up when new tasks appear
- Configurable min/max worker bounds
- Graceful worker shutdown (finish current task first)

Behavior:
- If 'bd ready' returns 0 tasks: reduce workers to minimum (default: 1)
- If tasks > workers: spawn more workers up to max (default: 10)
- Idle workers (waiting 60s+): graceful shutdown
- Keep 1 worker alive always to poll for new tasks
- Exponential backoff for spawning (prevent thrashing)

Requires:
- Orchestrator (beads-workers-gix) to manage worker lifecycle
- Worker health tracking
- Clean shutdown protocol

Config options (.beads/config.yaml):
  workers:
    min: 1           # Keep at least 1 alive
    max: 10          # Max concurrent workers
    scale-down-delay: 60   # Seconds idle before shutdown
    scale-up-threshold: 0.8  # Spawn when 80% busy

title: Implement orchestrator thread for request-response worker management
description:
Replace current polling model with orchestrator pattern:

Current: Each worker independently polls 'bd ready', races to claim tasks
Problem: Inefficient polling, race conditions, wasted DB queries

New architecture:
- Central orchestrator thread manages task queue
- Workers send REQUEST when ready for work
- Orchestrator assigns tasks via RESPONSE
- Uses named pipes or Unix sockets for IPC
- Orchestrator maintains worker availability state
- Single point of 'bd ready' queries (reduces contention)

Benefits:
- Eliminates race conditions
- Reduces database load
- Better task distribution
- Workers only work when tasks available
- Foundation for advanced scheduling (priority, affinity, etc.)

Implementation approach:
- Orchestrator runs as main process
- Workers communicate via FIFO pipes in /tmp/beads-workers-<pid>/
- Worker protocol: READY|DONE|FAILED messages
- Orchestrator protocol: TASK <issue-id>|WAIT|SHUTDOWN messages
